items.title: PPE firm linked to Michelle Mone misses deadline to repay £122m
items.standfirst: Firm was ordered by high court to return sum paid by DHSC for unusable surgical gowns by 4pm on WednesdayA company linked to the former Conservative peer Michelle Mone has failed to pay the government any of the £122m ordered by a high court judgment for supplying unusable personal protective equipment during the Covid pandemic.Mrs Justice Cockerill ruled that PPE Medpro must, by a deadline of 4pm on 15 October, return the money it was paid by the Department of Health and Social Care for 25m sterile surgical gowns under a contract awarded in June 2020. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

The gowns were deemed unusable by the Department of Health.

clusters.title: Who’s to blame for the NHS’s blame culture? | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS blame culture: Who is to blame?

items.title: Who’s to blame for the NHS’s blame culture? | Letters
items.standfirst: Dr David Zigmond, Dr Richard Sloan, Dr Eric Watts and Dr Ian Freeman respond to an article by the former health secretary Jeremy HuntJeremy Hunt’s article (Here’s the direct effect of our NHS blame culture: babies die. Tragedy after tragedy, it can’t go on, 9 October) will be welcome to many, especially those healthcare professionals who have had to endure the intimidating mistrust and adversarial working culture he describes.What is missing from his account is the seminal role of government’s NHS reforms in creating these problems. In particular, the creation, then proliferation, of commercialised and competing autarkic NHS trusts and outside providers over many years. This has generated a growing culture of corporate defensiveness and reputation anxiety. Within such conditions, practitioners then adapt to behave much like employees in large commercial organisations – they must show compliance, “loyalty”, conformity and seamless performance, albeit speciously. Continue reading...
items.content: Dr David Zigmond, Dr Richard Sloan, Dr Eric Watts and Dr Ian Freeman respond to an article by the former health secretary Jeremy HuntJeremy Hunt’s article (Here’s the direct effect of our NHS blame culture: babies die. Tragedy after tragedy, it can’t go on, 9 October) will be welcome to many, especially those healthcare professionals who have had to endure the intimidating mistrust and adversarial working culture he describes.What is missing from his account is the seminal role of government’s NHS reforms in creating these problems. In particular, the creation, then proliferation, of commercialised and competing autarkic NHS trusts and outside providers over many years. This has generated a growing culture of corporate defensiveness and reputation anxiety. Within such conditions, practitioners then adapt to behave much like employees in large commercial organisations – they must show compliance, “loyalty”, conformity and seamless performance, albeit speciously. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Jeremy Hunt's article discusses the NHS's blame culture and its effects.
The article highlights the role of government reforms in creating problems.
Commercialized NHS trusts and providers have created corporate defensiveness.
Practitioners adapt to behave like employees in large commercial organizations.
The article suggests a need to address the culture of mistrust.

clusters.title: Don’t give in to big pharma on drug pricing | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Drug pricing: Don't give in to big pharma

items.title: Don’t give in to big pharma on drug pricing | Letters
items.standfirst: Drug manufacturers may lament the UK’s drug prices, writes Simon Dixon, but the NHS should celebrate themWhile the chief executive of Eli Lilly may lament the UK’s drug prices (UK is ‘worst country in Europe’ for drug prices, says Mounjaro maker, 24 September), the NHS should celebrate them. The system put in place for evaluating the cost-effectiveness of new drugs is respected the world over and is successful in applying the principle that funding a new product should not damage the NHS as a whole. This principle of cost-effectiveness has led to widespread price reductions for the NHS that have allowed the service as a whole to benefit.The chief executive of Eli Lilly links the recent pausing or cancelling of pharmaceutical industry investments in the UK to drug pricing here, when these are down to the drug companies’ desperation to kowtow to Donald Trump. Continue reading...
items.content: Drug manufacturers may lament the UK’s drug prices, writes Simon Dixon, but the NHS should celebrate themWhile the chief executive of Eli Lilly may lament the UK’s drug prices (UK is ‘worst country in Europe’ for drug prices, says Mounjaro maker, 24 September), the NHS should celebrate them. The system put in place for evaluating the cost-effectiveness of new drugs is respected the world over and is successful in applying the principle that funding a new product should not damage the NHS as a whole. This principle of cost-effectiveness has led to widespread price reductions for the NHS that have allowed the service as a whole to benefit.The chief executive of Eli Lilly links the recent pausing or cancelling of pharmaceutical industry investments in the UK to drug pricing here, when these are down to the drug companies’ desperation to kowtow to Donald Trump. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS should celebrate the UK's drug prices, according to one writer.
The system for evaluating drug cost-effectiveness is respected globally.
Cost-effectiveness has led to widespread price reductions for the NHS.
Eli Lilly's CEO links investment pauses to drug pricing in the UK.
The writer believes the investment pauses are due to Trump's influence.

items.title: ‘Alarming rise’ in mental health stigma in England, research shows
items.standfirst: One in 10 people unwilling to live next to someone who has been mentally ill even if they have recovered, Mind reportsThe number of people in England who are frightened of living near people with mental health problems has nearly doubled to one in seven, which experts warn reflects an “alarming rise in stigma”.Even if the mentally ill person had recovered, one in 10 people said they would be unwilling to live next to them, according to new research from the mental health charity Mind. Continue reading...

clusters.title: ‘You are constantly told you are evil’: inside the lives of diagnosed narcissists
clusters.neutral_headline: Inside the lives of diagnosed narcissists

items.title: ‘You are constantly told you are evil’: inside the lives of diagnosed narcissists
items.standfirst: Few psychiatric conditions are as stigmatised or as misunderstood as narcissistic personality disorder. Here’s how it can damage careers and relationships – even before prejudice takes its tollThere are times when Jay Spring believes he is “the greatest person on planet Earth”. The 22-year-old from Los Angeles is a diagnosed narcissist, and in his most grandiose moments, “it can get really delusional”, he says. “You are on cloud nine and you’re like, ‘Everyone’s going to know that I’m better than them … I’ll do great things for the world’.”For Spring, these periods of self-aggrandisement are generally followed by a “crash”, when he feels emotional and embarrassed by his behaviour, and is particularly vulnerable to criticism from others. He came to suspect that he may have narcissistic personality disorder (NPD) after researching his symptoms online – and was eventually diagnosed by a professional. But he doesn’t think he would have accepted the diagnosis had he not already come to the conclusion on his own. “If you try to tell somebody that they have this disorder, they’ll probably deny it,” he says – especially if they experience feelings of superiority, as he does. “They’re in a delusional world that they made for themselves. And that world is like, I’m the greatest and nobody can question me.” Continue reading...
items.content: Few psychiatric conditions are as stigmatised or as misunderstood as narcissistic personality disorder. Here’s how it can damage careers and relationships – even before prejudice takes its tollThere are times when Jay Spring believes he is “the greatest person on planet Earth”. The 22-year-old from Los Angeles is a diagnosed narcissist, and in his most grandiose moments, “it can get really delusional”, he says. “You are on cloud nine and you’re like, ‘Everyone’s going to know that I’m better than them … I’ll do great things for the world’.”For Spring, these periods of self-aggrandisement are generally followed by a “crash”, when he feels emotional and embarrassed by his behaviour, and is particularly vulnerable to criticism from others. He came to suspect that he may have narcissistic personality disorder (NPD) after researching his symptoms online – and was eventually diagnosed by a professional. But he doesn’t think he would have accepted the diagnosis had he not already come to the conclusion on his own. “If you try to tell somebody that they have this disorder, they’ll probably deny it,” he says – especially if they experience feelings of superiority, as he does. “They’re in a delusional world that they made for themselves. And that world is like, I’m the greatest and nobody can question me.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article explores the lives of people with narcissistic personality disorder.
The disorder can damage careers and relationships.
One diagnosed narcissist describes feelings of superiority.
These feelings are often followed by a "crash".
The article discusses the stigma associated with the disorder.

clusters.title: Late-night pub openings aren’t in the right spirit | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Late-night pub openings aren’t in the right spirit | Letters: Readers respond to government plans for extending pub hours, highlighting the financial and health costs

items.title: Late-night pub openings aren’t in the right spirit | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to government plans for extending pub hours, highlighting the financial and health costs The government’s plan to extend licensing hours seems to be a rather desperate measure to encourage growth (Pubs to stay open until early hours in push for UK growth, 8 October). Will there be enough customers for pubs to afford the additional staffing and running costs of staying open later?Many pubs are already closing early on some evenings and perhaps not opening on others. If the government really wants to give licensed premises a boost, it should find a way of reducing the price of the drinks they sell, but this would be unpalatable when it’s looking for ways to raise taxes. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to government plans for extending pub hours, highlighting the financial and health costs The government’s plan to extend licensing hours seems to be a rather desperate measure to encourage growth (Pubs to stay open until early hours in push for UK growth, 8 October). Will there be enough customers for pubs to afford the additional staffing and running costs of staying open later?Many pubs are already closing early on some evenings and perhaps not opening on others. If the government really wants to give licensed premises a boost, it should find a way of reducing the price of the drinks they sell, but this would be unpalatable when it’s looking for ways to raise taxes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Readers are responding to government plans to extend pub licensing hours.
Concerns include financial and health costs associated with extended hours.
Some readers question the viability of pubs affording extra staffing costs.
Many pubs already close early or do not open on certain evenings.
Suggestions include reducing drink prices to boost licensed premises.
